Perform Simple T-Test with Clear Interpretation

Source: R/simple_ttest.R
simple_ttest.Rd

This function performs a one-sample or two-sample t-test and provides easy-to-understand results and interpretation.

Usage

simple_ttest(
  x,
  y = NULL,
  mu = 0,
  alternative = "two.sided",
  conf.level = 0.95,
  paired = FALSE
)

Arguments

x

A numeric vector for the first group or single sample

y

A numeric vector for the second group (optional, for two-sample test)

mu

The hypothesized population mean for one-sample test (default = 0)

alternative

Character string specifying the alternative hypothesis. Must be one of "two.sided" (default), "greater", or "less"

conf.level

Confidence level (default = 0.95)

paired

Logical indicating whether to perform a paired t-test (default = FALSE)

Value

A list containing:

test_type

Type of t-test performed

statistic

T-statistic value

p.value

P-value of the test

conf.int

Confidence interval

estimate

Sample mean(s)

interpretation

Plain English interpretation of results

significant

Logical indicating if result is statistically significant

Examples

# One-sample t-test
sample1 <- rnorm(30, mean = 105, sd = 10)
result1 <- simple_ttest(sample1, mu = 100)
print(result1$interpretation)
#> [1] "Based on the One-sample t-test with 30 observations: \n- Sample mean: 104.038 \n- T-statistic: 2.263 \n- P-value: 0.0313 \n- Result is statistically significant at 95 % confidence level \n- Conclusion: We reject the null hypothesis that the mean equals 100"

# Two-sample t-test
group1 <- rnorm(25, mean = 50, sd = 8)
group2 <- rnorm(25, mean = 55, sd = 8)
result2 <- simple_ttest(group1, group2)
print(result2$interpretation)
#> [1] "Based on the Two-sample t-test comparing 25 vs 25 observations: \n- Group 1 mean: 49.984 \n- Group 2 mean: 55.56 \n- Mean difference: -5.577 \n- T-statistic: -2.366 \n- P-value: 0.0222 \n- Result is statistically significant at 95 % confidence level \n- Conclusion: We reject the null hypothesis of equal means"
